security: The documents discuss ongoing interactions between the CIA and the ARRB regarding sensitive information related to the JFK assassination. Revealing these exchanges could expose the CIA's internal processes for handling such requests and potentially highlight areas of contention or disagreement, as demonstrated by ARRB's repeated follow-ups on unanswered requests. The memorandum from December 18, 1997 underscores the seriousness of the situation: “I am writing to follow-up on our telephone call earlier today and to convey my serious concern about the status of CIA's responses to the Review Board's requests for additional information and records...On many occasions we have been assured that responses would be forthcoming, only to have promised dates come and go without answers.”
summary: This collection of memoranda details the status of information requests from the Assassination Records Review Board (ARRB) to the CIA regarding JFK assassination records between 1996 and 1998, outlining specific requests, updates, and concerns about delays in CIA responses.
summary_one_paragraph: This set of memoranda, spanning from 1996 to 1998, documents the ongoing communication between the ARRB and the CIA concerning the ARRB's requests for information and records related to the JFK assassination. The documents include specific inquiries about individuals like David Vance Vanek and Mrs. G. Stanley Brown, issues such as Oswald’s contacts in Moscow, and broader requests for categories of information like cables, histories, and HTLINGUAL records. These memos reveal the ARRB’s repeated follow-ups and expressions of concern regarding delays and incomplete responses from the CIA, with increasing urgency to resolve outstanding requests.
title: Priority Requests from ARRB Staff and Status of CIA Responses
persons_mentioned: Mrs. G. Stanley Brown (Verna Deane Stebbens Brown)
